These millimeter waves, operating at frequencies between 24 GHz and 90 GHz, have been linked to a range of biological effects due to their unique physical properties. Studies have shown that exposure to such frequencies can cause thermal effects, leading to localized heating of the skin and superficial tissues, which may disrupt normal physiological functions.

Non-thermal effects are also a growing concern. Research has indicated that RF-EMF exposure can alter calcium ion levels in cells, leading to oxidative stress and DNA damage. This has been associated with increased risks of neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s, as well as disruptions in the blood-brain barrier, which can allow harmful substances to enter the brain.

There is also mounting evidence linking prolonged exposure to 5G radiation with sleep disturbances, headaches, fatigue, and cognitive impairments. These symptoms are consistent with electrohypersensitivity (EHS), a condition increasingly reported among populations living near high-density 5G infrastructure. While the World Health Organization and some regulatory bodies downplay these effects, independent scientific studies continue to highlight the need for stricter safety standards and further research into the long-term health impacts of 5G technology.
